name: tantalum mine operation and beneficiation | tantalum concentrate, 30% Ta2O5 | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24970/documentation

This dataset refers to the global average mining and beneficiation activities in order to produce 1 kg of tantalum concentrate (30% Ta2O5). Congo and Rwanda are the two major producers of tantalum con-centrate, being responsible for approximately 62% of the global mine production (Source: https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2020/mcs2020-tantalum.pdf). This dataset is a disaggregation of the activity ''tantalum production, powder, capacitor-grade'' as found in version 3.7 of the Ecoinvent da-tabase that produces tantalum powder from tantalite ore and has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography GLO, due to absence of regionalized dataset.;;Specific values (such as i) average ore grade for the GLO geography -0.03% instead of 0.0194% Ta2O5 - and consequently the amount of extracted ore from the ground, ii) the ore grade of the concentrate from 38% to 30% to represent today's situation as the grade of the concentrate 20-40 years ago was 40-45%) were changed to provide a more representative picture of the today's tantalum concentrate production. Furthermore, values such as electricity, water and diesel consumption were scaled based on the new amount of ore extracted from ground (approximately 1370 kg) and grade of the final concen-trate to ensure better representativeness (for more information consult the sampling procedure and the respective exchanges comments). The average global ore grade of tantalite ore ranges between 0.02%-0.04% Ta2O5 (Source: Mancheri et al (2018)). ;The original data are based on the Grenbushes and Wodgina mines in Western Australia, which at the time was the major producer of tantalum (55-60% of the global tantalum production). The original data and their underlying assumptions can be found in chapter 5.1.2, tables 5.2 & 5.3, part XI of the Classen et al (2009) report. Only production from tantalite ore and through open-pit mining is considered here, meaning that mining of tantalum from other ores (such as pyrochlore) or through other mining techniques (such artisanal mining) are not taken into account.;;Reference 1: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmeneg-ger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch.;Reference 2: Mancheri, N. A., Sprecher, B., Deetman, S., Young, S. B., Bleischwitz, R., Dong, L., . . . Tukker, A. (2018). Resilience in the tantalum supply chain. Resources, Conservation and Re-cycling, 129, 56-69. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.resconrec.2017.10.018). The average grade of 0.03% Ta2O5 has been con-sidered here. 

The activities start with the mining of the tantalum ore.

The activities end with the production of tantalum concentrate (30% beneficiated).

No allocation is applied.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Dataset considered valid for the entire corresponding region.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: At first, the tantalum minerals are extracted from the ground through open-pit mining. Standard pro-cess include drilling, blasting, and muck cycles prior to the beneficiation of the tantalum ore. After min-ing, tantalite ores are almost exclusively concentrated through wet gravity concentration, utilizing equipment such as jigs, spirals and tables, in order to produce low- to medium-grade concentrate. Centrifugal type concentrators could be used in the future to recover even finer tantalum particles, but there is no indication that the industry is moving towards that direction. The low- to medium-grade concentrates are further beneficiated in dry plants, where dry gravity concentrators, magnetic and elec-trostatic concentrators are used and sulfides are ocassionally removed by flotation. The tantalum con-tent of the resulting concentrate is usually between 25-35% (Source: Rob-ert Linnen, D.L. Trueman, Richard BurtTantalum and niobium Gunn, Gus (Eds.), 2014, Critical Metals Handbook: British Geological Survey (2014), pp. 361-384) or 20-40% Ta2O5 (according to figure 15.6 of the same source), which is lower than the required grade in the past (45-50% % Ta2O5). In general, concentrates from central Africa have higher Ta2O5 grades than those produced in Canada, Brazil or Australia.  However due to lack of data it is assumed that the average grade of Ta2O5 is 30%.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset is meant to be a global average representation, based on data of one company and some approximations (see sampling procedure). Uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly for the global dataset.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
This dataset refers to the global average mining and beneficiation activities in order to produce 1 kg of tantalum concentrate (30% Ta2O5). Congo and Rwanda are the two major producers of tantalum concentrate, being responsible for approximately 62% of the global mine production (Source: https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2020/mcs2020-tantalum.pdf). This dataset is a disaggregation of the activity ''tantalum production, powder, capacitor-grade'' as found in version 3.7 of the Ecoinvent database that produces tantalum powder from tantalite ore and has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography GLO, due to absence of regionalized dataset.

Specific values (such as i) average ore grade for the GLO geography -0.03% instead of 0.0194% Ta2O5 - and consequently the amount of extracted ore from the ground, ii) the ore grade of the concentrate from 38% to 30% to represent today's situation as the grade of the concentrate 20-40 years ago was 40-45%) were changed to provide a more representative picture of the today's tantalum concentrate production. Furthermore, values such as electricity, water and diesel consumption were scaled based on the new amount of ore extracted from ground (approximately 1370 kg) and grade of the final concentrate to ensure better representativeness (for more information consult the sampling procedure and the respective exchanges comments). The average global ore grade of tantalite ore ranges between 0.02%-0.04% Ta2O5 (Source: Mancheri et al (2018)). 

The original data are based on the Grenbushes and Wodgina mines in Western Australia, which at the time was the major producer of tantalum (55-60% of the global tantalum production). The original data and their underlying assumptions can be found in chapter 5.1.2, tables 5.2 & 5.3, part XI of the Classen et al (2009) report. Only production from tantalite ore and through open-pit mining is considered here, meaning that mining of tantalum from other ores (such as pyrochlore) or through other mining techniques (such artisanal mining) are not taken into account.

Reference 1: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch.

Reference 2: Mancheri, N. A., Sprecher, B., Deetman, S., Young, S. B., Bleischwitz, R., Dong, L., . . . Tukker, A. (2018). Resilience in the tantalum supply chain. Resources, Conservation and Re-cycling, 129, 56-69. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.resconrec.2017.10.018). The average grade of 0.03% Ta2O5 has been con-sidered here.

exchanges.description:
The original value is 155466 kWh and represents tha amount of electricity consumption required for the production of 1000 kg of tantalum pentoxide content in the concentrate (or 2632 kg of concentrate), with a grade of 38% Ta2O5. These original values were taken from Table 5.3, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. The amount of electricity was first adjusted to correspond to the production of 1 kg of tantalite ore (by diving the amount of electricity consumption by 7067000 kg of ore - same source as mentioned above). The resulting value was then multiplied with 1370, as 1370 kg of tantalite ore are required for the production of 1 kg of concentrate with a grade of 30% Ta2O5 (see gangue, in ground exchange comment).
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE

exchanges.description: The land occupation value is 7.85E-02 m2a/ t ore is taken fromTable 5.2, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. However, after internal review within Ecoinvent, there may be wrong reporting of the value in the abovementioned source, For this exchange, it is assumed that the units of the value is in m2 / t ore instead of m2*year / t ore as originally reported. Therefore, the value has to be multiplied by 50, since the mine is assumed to be operating for 50 years. The original value originated from the company Sons of Galia.The amount of ore extracted for the production of 1 kg of concentrate is 1370 kg (see gangue, in ground comment).

exchanges.description:
The value represents the amount of tantalum that needs to be extracted from the ground for the production of 1 kg of tantalum concentrate (30% Ta2O5). This value is obtained by multiplying the amount of tantalum ore extracted from the ground (1370 kg - more information on the gangue exchange comment) with i) the grade of tantalum contained in the ore and ii) the subtotal mass of tantalum in Ta2O5. The global ore grade of tantalite ore is 0.02%-0.04% Ta2O5 (Source: Mancheri, N. A., Sprecher, B., Deetman, S., Young, S. B., Bleischwitz, R., Dong, L., . . . Tukker, A. (2018). Resilience in the tantalum supply chain. Resources, Conservation and Recycling, 129, 56-69. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.resconrec.2017.10.018).
The average value of 0.03% Ta2O5 is taken into account here.	
The subtotal masses of Ta2O5 are: Ta:81.90% , O:18.90%.

exchanges.description: The value represents the amount of gangue that is extracted from the ground for the production of 1 kg of tantalum concentrate (30% Ta2O5). This value is obtained by subtracting the amount of tantalum extracted from the ore (0.336575 kg-see tantalum, in ground comment) from the amount of total ore that is extracted from the ground. The latter amount is calculated based on the following facts: i) The average ore grade in Congo is 0.03302% Ta2O5 (see tantalum in ground comment). ii) The recovery efficiency of tantalum during mining and beneficiation is between 72%-74% (Source: Roethe, G. (1989). Processing of Tantalum and Niobium Ores, Berlin, Heidelberg). The average value of 73% is considered here and iii) the concentrate ore grade is 30% Ta2O5. This results approximately in an amount of approximately 1370  kg of extracted tantalite ore.
